Best games of past generation:
2007: Call of Duty 4 - Modern Warfare; BioShock; Assassin's Creed
2008: Metal Gear Solid IV; Fallout 3; Grand Theft Auto IV
2009: Uncharted 2; Batman Arkham Asylum
2010: Red Dead Redemption, Heavy Rain; God of War III
2011: Skyrim; Mortal Kombat; Batman Arkham City
2012: The Walking Dead; Far Cry 3
2013: Bioshock Infinite; The Last of Us; Grand Theft Auto V

author: Deven Jericho

text: @Deven Jericho¬†I have the money to buy one right now, but I really don't want to buy it for $350. I have a Wii U already with a ton of games that I still need to beat (Xenoblade Chronicles X has especially been sucking up a ton of my time) so I can wait until the end of the generation when they will have released an upgraded version of the console for a cheaper price (and even if they don't, I still get it for $250 or so, plus cheaper used games).
author: Jordan3D

text: +Jordan3D That's true about the used games but the PS4 is so worth the 350 bucks because of many other games and more to come. But I don't know if they price will ever lower to much because the PS3 didn't really lower until the PS4 came out and the PS3 was out for awhile.
author: Deven Jericho

text: @Deven Jericho¬†I think the games look good, but there's not really any on the system that I would be willing to spend $40+ on. Once the PS5 comes out, the PS4 will be at least a bit cheaper and the games will be $20-$30 instead. Plus I also want to wait on the NX and see if they can get third party support so that I don't buy a weaker system for the same games.

text: @SlapstickCoyote No, they don't round up. That's what I've been telling you. This isn't high school algebra class. You're assuming way too much.
author: Aara

text: @SlapstickCoyote 1% to 5%? No, that's not how it works. That would be assuming scores are assigned randomly, which they aren't. Yes, there are fewer scores, but like I said, they are not all weighted equally. A ten is a top-of-the-line game. If a game isn't that, then it can't be a ten and would therefore be a 9.5. If a game would have previously been a 9.8, that means it's not 10.0 material and therefore would get a 9.5.
author: Aara

text: @SlapstickCoyote It doesn't increase the odds at all. If a games perfect, they give it a ten. If there are any flaws, it therefore doesn't deserve a ten and therefore the highest it could get is now a 9.5. A 10 is still a 10.
author: Aara

text: @SlapstickCoyote It's more likely that they'll mark them down to 9.5 than mark them up to 10. Greg Miller said on Podcast Beyond that whenever a reviewer gives a game a 10, they have to check with a few other reviewers and the bosses also check it out before giving it. He said that's what happened with Uncharted 3 in response to people accusing him of being a fanboy. I doubt reviewers would go through that effort if they're increasing it from say a 9.8 to a 10
